body_html:
@harshini-gadige @fchollet I'm also seeing this with the MobileNetV2 model. I see it when using the tf.keras.load_model with version tf.keras.__version__ = 2.1.6-tf. However, when using keras.load_model with version keras.__version__ = 2.2.4 it loads the model properly.

Update: 10/16/18
I've actually determined that tf.keras.models.save_model generates models that cannot be read by either pure keras.models.load_model or tf.keras.models.load_model when working with MobileNetV1/2 based networks.

Hope that helps!
body_text:
@harshini-gadige @fchollet  I'm also seeing this with the MobileNetV2 model. I see it when using the tf.keras.load_model with version tf.keras.__version__ = 2.1.6-tf. However, when using keras.load_model with version keras.__version__ = 2.2.4 it loads the model properly.
Update: 10/16/18
I've actually determined that tf.keras.models.save_model generates models that cannot be read by either pure keras.models.load_model or tf.keras.models.load_model when working with MobileNetV1/2 based networks.
Hope that helps!
body:
@harshini-gadige @fchollet  I'm also seeing this with the `MobileNetV2` model. I see it when using the `tf.keras.load_model` with version `tf.keras.__version__ = 2.1.6-tf`. However, when using `keras.load_model` with version `keras.__version__ = 2.2.4` it loads the model properly. 

**Update: 10/16/18**
I've actually determined that `tf.keras.models.save_model` generates models that cannot be read by either pure `keras.models.load_model` or `tf.keras.models.load_model` when working with MobileNetV1/2 based networks. 

Hope that helps!
